Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Open glade near ridgetop. Just down the ridge from the Na size 3.5 we reported which occurred on Thursday or Friday (Jan 26-27) during warming event. Caribou Ridge maxed at +7C! Suspect windslab release with step down.

Notable wind slab in mid and higher elevations.
Triggering these slabs will remain possible today at and above treeline, and these slabs will need a bit more time to help heal up. Be very aware of density changes underfoot and visual signs of wind effected snow.
decomposing crust 3-7cm

2110 meters. Pit dug to assess buried surface hoar layers and November facets. Buried surface hoar layers from 1/22, 1/12, and 1/6 did not propagate a fracture, nor did the November crust facet combo. The 1/22 SH and November Facets were reactive in small block tests and Deep Tap. Layers are seemingly healing... slowly. No collapsing, cracking or reaction to skiing on slopes to 35 degrees. SS-Ny-R2-D2-O initiated by loose snow hitting debris fan causing a small wind slab with step down to PWL 1/3 way down apron. Likely triggered within 48 hours on Dorval Peak out of prominent East Couloir.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: TL, krumholzen, open slopes, blueberry and heather groundcover
Near road south of patrol building, not on a ski trail, representative of backcountry conditions.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Quick pit to assess buried surface hoar and basal facets. No collapsing or cracking in area. We triggered one small wind slab on a south facing cross-loaded feature. 20-30cm deep x 5m wide. Size 1 would be generous for this 45 degree wind lip. No reaction to skiing on south aspects.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Avalanche was 300' wide and ran 250' vertical feet. Average depth was 1' and deepest was 2'. Skier triggered on the skiers left side. Not reported to the ASP. Failure was crust facet sandwich 64-70cm from the surface. Faceted stellars and mixed rounding facets were the weak layer. Scored a 4.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Avalanche was 300' wide and ran 250' vertical feet. Average depth was 1' and deepest was 2'. Skier triggered on the skiers left side. Not reported to the ASP. Failure was crust facet sandwich 64-70cm from the surface. Faceted stellars and mixed rounding facets were the weak layer. Scored a 4.
Winds out of the southwest coming lightly up valley, but moving westerly aloft. Bushes were encountered near the surface but could not be avoided within the pit

Pit_Observation.activities: Poor pit location;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug below ridgetop in previously wind loaded place.
No results in CT or ECT, but and informal "32nd" tap (two extra hard taps) produced a propagating failure in small facets above the Jan 14th facet crust

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Final exam day with CAA OPS LVL1. Pit objective: investigate the condition of the near-surface MFcr and the prominent upper-snowpack MFcr down 25-50 plus the upper/lower interfaces of each. Pit location characteristics: sun/wind exposed, planar, open glades at TL.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Surprised by some test results at location.
Westerly breezy winds with interesting "cotton ball" snow falling while we were out there. -7.8 at 1425 from IR and -6.8 from the thermometer.
Stable layers. Nothing of major concern. Recent wind loading was bonding well

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Noted dry loose avalanches on steeper east facing slopes both skier and natural triggered within the surface snow 4-6" deep. We did not see any wind-drifted snow issues and were on the lookout for this problem.

Found persevered SH at 80cm and 100cm down small crust down 22cm with noticeable spotty SH through interface
Jan 12th SH interface well preserved SH 3-5 mm Jan 5th SH interface well preserved SH 3-5 mm

Did not find @195 SH until CT test, SH is Subtle but definitely there. Would have guessed results around 1/13 @200cm, but In this location: No results above or below 1/13 crust. @198 moderate shovel shear and @118 (irregular plane)mod-hard SS on ECT column.
Height of Snowpack 140cm Areas adjacent to pit with free water at bottom 20-40cm of snowpack

Test profile to investigate Jan. 13 MFcr with CAA OPS LVL1. Profile was dug on a planar slope, in open glades BTL, it was wind sheltered but sun exposed.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Surface snow was not wind affected. 20m to the West, on the Ridge, lots of wind erosion in the trees from previous N and NW winds.

Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: wind scoured surface with some sastruggi visible. Pit dug between bomb areas/gazex and no bomb residue visible in the pit/layers.

Observers: Nathan Friesen, Rose Frouin Profile dug in a shallow area on the north end of operational area at treeline. Jan 14 MFcr presents as a layer of greater resistance but not a crust, suspect less precip in this area during that rain event. Dec 26 MFcr presents as thin, laminated decomposing crusts, trending towards facetted polycrystals.

Snow profile with CAA OPS LVL1 to gain further baseline info on snowpack. The pit was dug on a planar slope, it was in open glades at treeline and it was wind/sun exposed.
Snow science with Wes Gregg.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Signs of recent avalanche activity on the gunners left side of the upper couloir. Lower section had signs of avalanche debris on bed surface. Throughout the tour we observed spin drift on the steep cliffs and while descending our lower boot pack was filled back in with dry loose snow falling down the cliffs.
Winds picked up upon return home. IR temperature taken at 1014 with a value of -9.3 and thermometer had -4.7C

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Moderate to strong east winds at 8600'. Ridgetop winds were strong from the west and northwest. Broken skies upon approach and then overcast to obscured skies with limited visibility to the ridgetops. Probing in numerous locations it did feel as though were about 10cm of softer (faceted?/mixed) grains on the ground.

Collapsing, localized;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Previous wind scouring across slopes from the N/NW. Very cold temps 0 degrees F overnight and cold (-10C) during the day. Large amount to wind scouring, but not affecting the midpack in most areas NTL and BTL. Previous WS with crown 2-3m high on E face of the Pyramid, running 3/5 of the entire face and the full runout. Likely post-cycle days earlier.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit with CAA OPS L1. Baseline observations at TL - investigating the various crusts in the snowpack. High skier traffic area; no evidence of tracks through pit but lower layers may have been affected in the past.

Adjacent to road. Structure generally similar to surrounding paths except some areas had two buried rain crusts instead of one. HS varied between 15-80cm but averaged 50-60cm up to 6500'. Old, dead slab on a decomposing crust over facets. Weak structure, but good stability for now. Facet sluffing in top 5-8 cm of snow.

Pit_Observation.activities: Snowmobile tracks on slope;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Winds NNW gusting to moderate at the highest ridges. RR crust with .5mm NSF on any slope taking solar energy. Noted some dry loose avalanches from a cornice drop on E facing at 9900'. Isolated areas of wind drifted snow on steep leeward aspects was still suspect. Cloud deck moved through during the day. Hovered around 7000' for the afternoon.
Wind-sheltered, representative location for the northern rim of the Grand Mesa. 13.5 inches of water in the slab overlying the mid-November dry spell facet layer.
Variable HS, open trees, steep roll 50m below ridge top

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: No collapsing, cracking, or avalanche activity seen on tour. Several 1-2" depth dry loose point releases on steep terrain.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug adjacent to a wide propagating avalanche that occurred sometime the night of Jan 18. Crown was no longer visible due to post storm NE wind scouring. Debris blocks appeared to be 1 foot or less in thickness. NTL terrain. Unable to probe to ground. HS > 3.5 m

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit was dug in a seldom traveled area of Breckenridge Ski Resort. This terrain has only been open to the public for several days and there were no tracks visible nearby. This pit was dug 120cm deep; ground is 160cm deep- this pit is not dug to ground. Of note: 2 thermometers were used to take snowpack temps and their calibration to each other may have been a degree or two off.
